title: Don’ts

metadata.author: Nina Evason
metadata.note: All research and editorial content is developed and curated by Mosaica.

description: Behaviours to avoid in order to maintain respect and harmony in Malaysian social and cultural contexts.

guidelines.text: Avoid directly criticising someone, pointing out mistakes, or giving insincere compliments, as these actions can cause a Malaysian to lose ‘face’.
Do not publicly humiliate anyone; this conflicts with cultural principles of respect and can severely damage relationships.
Avoid publicly displaying anger, raising your voice, or shouting in front of elders or superiors; confrontational behaviour is seen as ‘kasar’ (crass/rough) and is strongly disapproved.
Refrain from interrupting or filling silences during conversation; patience and listening are valued.
Do not criticise Malaysia or the Malay royal family; even if a local does so, it is best to listen without indicating agreement or disagreement.
Avoid discussing the sensitive topic of ethnic relations in Malaysia; opinions can vary widely depending on personal background and experience.
